title: Great service
body: I attended for COVID-19 vaccine, everything went smoothly and they were giving biscuits at the end! Both staff and volunteers very friendly

readBy.name: Cambridgeshire And Peterborough NHS Foundation Trust

title: Outstanding!
body: Breast clinic staff were fantastic. After being greeted by a friendly receptionist all my worries were eased. Nurses were great, explained everything that would happen & the consultant, mamogram nurses & ultrasound nurses were amazing.

readBy.name: South Tees Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Dreadful
body: Tried to phone for a appointment  at 8.45am still waiting at 14.30 no answer, What is going on? This is dreadful service and a morning wasted. Don’t go to this surgery.

title: Fantastic service
body: Amazing staff I broke my arm I’m grateful  made me feel so much calm I would of been lost without there help

title: Very satisfied.
body: I sent a message to the surgery in the morning. The doctor called me the same afternoon and sent my prescription straight to the chemist. Very satisfied.

title: Excellent care
body: Excellent care provided for my chronic condition throughout the pandemic. Receptionists friendly and helpful and able to get appointments when needed. The GP’sand nurses hard work is greatly appreciated and my family and I feel well cared for. Phone system Can require some patience but the required assistance has always been reached eventually. Fantastic work everyone despite the challenges of the last 24 months. Thank you.

title: Poor service
body: First visit,Large spot on my back.Treatment apply ointment no change in seize or swelling.Second treatment take antibiotics adverse side effects.Third treatment change antibiotics no change in size or swelling.Forth treatment with nurse unable to treat. Sent to A&E informed should not have been sent to A&E treatment required day surgery.referring me back to GP to arrange final treatment.In total seven visits,Totally Inadequate

title: Terrible Experience
body: After having a fall & being in immense pain with my wrist & a swollen ankle, I called 111 & was referred to NDH. On arriving, security was on the door & unstandably would only allow myself in. I had to wait in the corridor to be called to A&E reception. I was called in & as I gave my details to 1 receptionist I noticed another was scrolling through 'The Independent' online. I waited in the waiting room until a nurse called for me. We stood in the waiting room & discussed why I was there. She sent me to x-ray. Off I hobbled down the corridor & waited for my turn. Told the radiographer what was wrong, both my wrist & ankle. My wrist was x-rayed, which caused more pain as she asked me to turn it & move it. I was then sent back to a room opposite A&E. Off I hobbled. 3 receptionist sat there chatting amongst themselves. I approached & told them I had been sent by x-ray, 1 told me to take a seat & someone will call for me. 4th waiting area! A man come & got me. I don't know who he was, or what his profession was, he never told me. I hobbled back down to a room opposite x-ray. 5th area! He examined my wrist, asked 'does it hurt' etc. He then left the room. Another man entered the room, looked surprised to see me. He apologised saying he thought room was empty & proceded to go through the cupboards before leaving. I was left alone again. The first man returned, examined my wrist again. He then began to expain what he thought was wrong. As he spoke he made no eye contact. He stumbled over his words & repeated himself often. He then went to a cupboard, while explaining that I could have a scapuloid break, but this was difficult to diagnose & the treatment for it would be the same, some wrist band/splint thing. He searched the cupboard, I observed him check the 'medium' box at least 4 times, (each time it was empty) he tried a small on me, but realising it didn't fit he placed back in the cupboard & settled on large. He said I needed to go back to reception to book an appointment for a follow up. He explained these were only available on Mondays (2 days time) & I would probably have to wait until the week after, but I could cancel if my pain had gone. Hobbled back to wait in the corridor which is where I started. I was in so much pain, too warm & becoming very frustrated & anxious. Security had left & a nurse was now there. After about 10 mins I asked if someone else could book the appointment. The nurse was lovely, apologised for the wait but told me I would have to wait. I stated my frustration, asking what exactly was taking so long when there was obviously staff sitting about not appearing to be working. She looked over at the receptionists who were talking & advised they must be talking about a patient I said I would hope not! I was eventually called up, handed over the paper I had been given, to be told to take a seat. Really! For the 7th time I had to wait again. 5 different areas! 3 hours with no pain relief! I'll go to Shotley or QE if I ever need

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

title: A&E
body: I'm so upset at the attitude of reception and nurses this evening.  Having been advised to attend with a problem I was spoken to like a waste of space. Rude, unkind and disinterested.  Having been a nurse for 30 years I have never ever behaved this way towards patients.  I walked out in utter disgust and will never go to this place again.

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Derby and Burton NHS Foundation Trust

title: Terrible
body: Waiting over 1 hour for the call to be answered on numerous occasions, being belittled by the new receptionist as of August 2021 the surgery is still not open and you still have to give your personal details through an intercom on the street with others passing by or waiting. Don't even think you'll be able to make an appointment for the next day or even after 1pm. Appointments are given 8-1 and if you want 2-6 you need to call after 1 and you definitely won't see a GP! You'll get a call back at some point which suits them....talking private things on the bus really isn't appropriate.

title: Fantastic team minor injuries
body: My daughter had a severe burn whilst camping in Cornwall- we needed to get it re-dressed on Saturday and we’re unable to see a nurse at our medical practice at Cumberland House Stone.  We were advised to go to the Haywood Hospital to get it dressed there. Upon arrival the receptionist advised us that we could not be seen and that we had to go to Leek. I felt very frustrated as my daughter’s dressing needed seeing to. I telephoned Leek and they spoke to the nurse who advised we were more than welcome. I also spoke to Stafford hospital as they are only 9 miles from our home and they said to go to Stoke A&E! We arrived at Leek and we were seen promptly and received a very professional warm welcome. The staff could not have been more helpful and they worked collaboratively and efficiently. I could not have asked for a better service. They also managed to arrange an appointment for Monday at the burns unit at Stoke on Monday 16th August. They are a credit to the NHS. The value that a small hospital that serves the community can not be and should not be underestimated.

title: Lack of professionalism
body: Drove from the south coast to Ealing, waited over an hour to be seen only to find the Doctor didn't turn up and phoned in sick, no alternative, ended up with a refund, total waste of time No compensation for being put out disgusting, these companies playing doctor and nurses shouldn't be allowed

title: Lifecycle Mental Health
body:
I tried to talk to someone with regards to access to an employment advisor.

I spoke to someone by phone.

I felt it was like talking to an emotionless robot.

I was forced to go through these survey questions that I did not want to do. I had to give up half-way through as it was unhelpful to me and upsetting me.

It was a terrible experience.

readBy.name: South Tyneside and Sunderland NHS Foundation Trust

title: Excellent service
body: Can not speak highly enough of the friendly and efficient service. I was naturally rather nervous before , but the friendly service was so good. The doctor and support service were clearly a well established and highly experienced in a specialist area, which really showed. The specialist doctor was reassuringly informative throughout and nice to know some of the nurses had supported the same doctor for over 10 years . The discharge nurse took exceptional care to explain matters and arrange for my wife to meet me.  An exceptional example of our NHS at its very best, despite tremendous pressures. Truly shameful to note so many abuse such a service by not turning up, over 5000 last month, when so many desperate for our NHS service.

title: Thank You so much
body: Thank you to all the staff, nurses and the surgeons at Spa Medica Bedford that have given me my sight back and my life back, painlessly removing cataracts from both my eyes and giving me fantastic, colourful vision that I had forgotten existed, thank you again, Richard from St Neots age 63.

title: What a disappointment derriford emergency is!
body: Was taken into hospital via ambulance yesterday at 9pm to be left in a side room all night until 6:30am this morning, I called the call bell and had to wait at least 15-30 minutes for someone to respond to me, the staff seemed so up right and annoyed by everyone needing help, the whole atmosphere was horrendous, staff literally sat accumulated round a desk talking about their home life’s and laughing and noises that patients are making as their in pain! Really rude and so dissatisfied with the services provided, I really wish there was another hospital in Plymouth me and my family could attend rather than derriford...

title: Great Experience
body: Surprised and amazed at the level of great care provided by the nursing staff I cannot fault them in any way what so ever 8 days of wonderful support by the nurses in ward 3 level 8 they where very caring and understanding of people and the operations that we the patients have had add to this the catering support staff also deserve  little praise as well but with this kind of great care also comes with a certain level of failure by the hospital firstly the blow up air bed that I had to stay on was and is in my opinion the worst experience of my stay in your hospital not only extremely uncomfortable but also caused a 8 days lack of real rest and sleep I would recommend that the hospital stop the use immediately who provides the food delivered to the wards are they pre-prepared and delivered in bulk or are they pre-prepared on site if brought in then the hospital should re-evaluate this use as soon as it would be possible but if cooked on site then I am ashamed to say the quality in my opinion was not good as with sandwiches which have less than 24 hours before they would need to be thrown away such a waste but that will be my only comment on this so to conclude I my overall stay was a great experience and I cannot praise the support that I received from the under-rated nurses any higher than they are absolutely superb .

readBy.name: Digestive Diseases Centre, Royal Sussex County Hospital

title: Awful Practice
body:
Patients treated like lepers.  The very elderly and infirm, and heavily pregnant ladies told to wait outside in the cold to be seen for 20-30 minutes, with no shelter and no-where to sit, meanwhile reception was empty.

I'm sure this practice will hide behind 'guidelines', but for me that is no excuse.  Of course it doesn't matter because no-one is measuring the harm and suffering caused by asking people who are already sick to stand waiting for 30 minutes in the cold and wet to get seen.

As a younger person I was ok to stand waiting outside, but they could've removed half of the seats inside and created a socially distanced space for the most vulnerable who feel the need to sit down, due to whatever medical ailment they had.

Covid has highlighted the difference between organisations who want to help people and those who simply use the crisis as an excuse to make their own lives easier, or earn more money.

title: Successful total knee replacement
body: I have had two successful total knee replacements at this hospital within the last year. I would highly recommend this hospital to anyone. I was very satisfied with the whole experience. The staff were friendly, the food was excellent, and follow up appointments were thorough. Thank you!

title: Bad treatement
body:
Sent to the hospital by the NHS physiotherapist for urgent treatment on my knee. It was made very plain to me by the Spire specialist that I was an NHS patient in a private hospital. I was given a cursory examination and told to go away and take Ibuprofen.
When I asked why my knee was giving out and I was falling over I was told it was just a symptom of arthritis’s and to take Ibuprofen and live with it.

title: Not helpful
body:
I was very very ill and forced myself in the condition I was to go to the GP and they said you need to do an ONLINE consultation.!!!
And when I did the result literally stated I will seek medical advise myself!
What the heck?!!
And if it’s very severe call 111
Never ever going there again.

title: Good healthcentre
body: Hello had a cervical mri scan on the 14/08/2021 at your waterloo branch.All i can say is the good service recieved from all your staff was friendly and welcoming.

title: Shocking
body:
It would appear they delete any negative reviews on here so just go and look on Google maps reviews.
Mostly very similar experiences from the same people working there. Now, you'd think theyd take notice of public opinion but they clearly do not, even when most people refer to one person in particular which leads me to believe it isn't about providing local care, it's about receiving government money.
I'll not mention who it was I spoke to because they will just delete it because it would encourage people to go elsewhere (isn't that the point of leaving a review?)
Coronavirus or no coronavirus, we're all stressed and tired but I don't get rudeness like that from people in the local shop, petrol station, or the city hospital. I hope they shut it down and retrain their staff

readBy.name: Cambridgeshire And Peterborough NHS Foundation Trust

title: Great patient care
body:
Was admitted to Majors A & E following a Blood pressure issue. 
The staff were incredibly busy as the department was overflowing with patients, however as soon as I could be seen by nurses/doctors the care and attention I received was second to none. All of the staff who looked after me were a credit to their profession.
It is obvious that the staff there do their job for love and not for money, and that also includes the paramedics who took me to the Southampton General A & E dept.
Am so proud of our NHS staff and the work they do, especially during the last 18 months having to deal with a pandemic as well.
Thank you to the staff at the Southampton General A & E for helping me and for the wonderful work you do.

title: Check list
body: Check list experience, therapist jumped from problem to problem only giving a week to work on each one and seemed uninterested, she was always late even when being the first appointment of the morning, for me struggling with anxiety disorder this was not helpful, as soon as my score went down I was referred back to my gp, I did have the choice to continue however with how things had gone I chose not to, such a shame because its taken me years to build up the courage to attend therapy

title: Excellent
body: Husband's p.s.a was raised again after many years of being in in remission from prostate cancer. Just over three weeks from being referred by GP. Telephone consultation arranged. Bond scan and M.R.I within 4 days of consultation and appointment at Urology 10 days later to get result. Treatment started straight away and another consultation a fortnight later arranged. Can't praise department enough.

readBy.name: Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust

title: An incredible experience - delivered by…
body:
(Labour Ward/Birth Centre - St Mary's Paddington) 

We recently used the maternity facilities (labour ward and birth centre) at St Mary's and could not speak more highly of the teams in both departments! 

We were super lucky to get a room in each and were enormously grateful for that and the treatment received.

Warmth, patience, support, knowledge, guidance, empathy, generosity and kindness - were all shown in absolute abundance. It was a birth with a few challenges - but they were all overcame by the tireless staff - each of whom couldn't do enough for mum and baby - all without fuss. All delivered with good spirits, humour and a smile - even at 3.30am. 

Some of the machinery was having a bad day and not performing as it should (or at all) but all of the nurses calmly worked together to solve the technical issues - without drama or fuss. 

The NHS is one of the last few things that as a nation we all hold so dearly to our hearts (it's an absolute outrage that they / you are treated so poorly). The dozen or so nursing members that we were lucky enough to meet and work with over a 24 hour period could not do enough for us and make the experience as special as possible. It was just incredible. The care, love and above and beyond service was very, very overwhelming. 

Thank you so, so, SO much to all of the hardworking teams in both the labour and birth centre - it was an absolute honour to be in your company and we cannot thank you enough for everything you did and gave us. 

We wish you all the very best in your constant and ridiculous fight with government - you are VERY special people, you are the BEST people and we cannot thank you enough for everything that you do for us.

Biggest thank, deepest love and gratitude to Jen and all of the teams in the Labour Ward and Birth Centre - thank you SO much xxx

title: Prompt response
body:
I rang the surgery because my phone consultation had been marked completed, although nobody had rung.
The receptionist replied within 5 rings and was extremely helpful when I explained I had been wanting to speak to the GP. She texted him as I was on the phone and said he would get in touch. She was very reassuring.
I was so relieved to get a call almost immediately from the GP, who put my mind at rest.
That is what I call good service! Thank you Farfield GPs and the reception staff.

title: Great efficient team.
body: *Cataract lens placement》The surgeon and all the theatre team and nurses were wonderful. Made me relaxed and comfortable. Eye sight got so poor I could not see my keyboard keys. Now have excellent vision.  Thank you.

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

title: Excellent care
body: I visited the A&E department yesterday and cannot praise the staff highly enough.  From assessment to discharge they took excellent care of me.  In particular, the nurse who plastered my leg was brilliant.  She was professional, kind and efficient.  Thank you very much.

title: Amazing
body: I had an outpatient colonoscopy today to which I was a little nervous about as I have never had this procedure before but every single staff member was friendly , warm , efficient , professional , in what is a very busy time for the NHS . I came home feeling that it was not a traumatic experience at all . They were all great 😊

title: Face and neck swelling and all over rash
body: Reassuring I was rushed to AE they were brilliant.I am now on the mend new what treatment to give me feeling great now thank you so much.

title: Fantastic Endoscopy Department
body: This was my 3rd colonoscopy procedure at Leigh Endoscopy Unit and as always the staff were professional, friendly, patient and reassuring. The unit was spotless and covid safety measures were in place at all times. Definitely could not get better care even if you paid to go private. Well done to the team.

readBy.name: Wrightington, Wigan and Leigh NHS Trust

title: Great practice
body:
I have visited this hospital on several occasions and the experience has not changed. I am a nervous patient, but always feel at ease. I would highly recommend this hospital for the level of care and treatment I have received. I also left the hospital feeling well informed. 

Thanks to all.

title: Amazing
body: Could not fault the hard work and support from all the team in Caroline Ward (Atkinson & Morley) the ward is amazing nice and clean friendly dedicated hard working could not fault

title: Kind caring hands
body:
Such caring staff. 
My sister is in kind hands.
They always make me welcome and fully informed of my sisters health.
Home from home and reassurance during lockdown when I was unable to visit.

title: Excellent practice
body:
As a Long Covid patient since spring 2020, I have had a tough time.  However, in this unpleasant situation, it is my great good fortune to be a Woodlands patient.  My named GP and other doctors in the practice have listened to me and treated me with respect, professionalism and honesty.  When I read in Long Covid social media groups about the experiences of others, it is clear that this is not a universal experience. My GP and others in the practice have referred me for tests, enrolled me in appropriate rehabilitation programmes, and prescribed medication for individual symptoms. They have also had the honesty to say that there is a lot about Long Covid that is not yet fully known.  I am sure that this excellent patient care happens partly because the Woodlands GPs, in spite of the immense pressure that the pandemic has put on them, are committed to evidence-based practice and to the importance of listening to patients.
   I am also impressed with the ways in which the Woodlands administration has found ways of coping with pandemic pressures, both in terms of keeping patients safe and in terms of the huge increase in demand on the practice.  I have used the e-consult option with success and received prompt and professional responses (although there is sometimes a need to, erm, be economical with the truth on some of the questions on the form so that you don't get told to go to ER).  Good use is also made of text messages: for doctors to give appointments, for appointment reminders, and for post-appointment surveys to continue improving processes.
   I would also like to say that the reception staff, on the telephone and at my rare in-person visits, have been unfailingly efficient, courteous, and understanding.
   So - well done, Woodlands.  You make things more bearable.

title: Awfully long waiting times
body: I had to attend A&E and was made to wait TEN hours to get seen, then the nurse sorted me out in 5 minutes... wasted my entire day.

readBy.name: North West Anglia NHS Foundation Trust

title: Rubbish
body: You say don’t ring reception between 8/10 am as they are busy     I got through at 15/45 pm only to be told ring back at 8 am the next morning got through next morning at 10-30 am next morning only to be told to ring back the next morning at 8am impossible to get through at 8am yet every time I get through I am told to ring back at 8 am the next morning in other words I cannot get an appointment because I am told to ring back at 8 am the next morning in between all this my symptoms get worse all I wanted was a prescription would have taken no longer than 5 minutes when I persisted the receptionist found me a appointment 3 weeks later on 24/8/2021 symptoms just got worse I can see a dentist I can see a option yet I cannot see a doctor the system is broken it’s is useless we cannot be told every time we get through after 10am to phone back the next morning I have never criticised the NHS they are marvellous and I am 77 years old but this system is bloody useless

title: On line experience
body: Just getting used to being a new patient and my head around the online aspect . Practice is good at replying to messages . Unfortunately I missed a blood test appointment on Saturday . However even the online service is not available out of hours which strikes me as rather inefficient . Why not leave the option open acknowledge the message with an auto generated reply and then deal with the message when the practice reopens . I wanted to apologise for missing the appointment and rebook but I now have to wait two days to submit another form .

title: Compassion and care
body:
I was referred to an MRI due to some neck and dizziness issues. The  scanner was in a mobile unit out the back. The technician came to collect me from the meeting point. They asked why I chose a faraway scanner (I'm not local). I needed a more open MRI due to claustrophobia which for me turns to a panic attack. Having a panic attack just means the procedure is stopped and can't be continued. This has happened to me before at Pilgrim and I was treated as an annoyance and time-waster. So I was really reluctant to go back here.
I told the technician that I get anxious but they made no comment. One of the technicians did offer to place a pad under my neck to add some comfort and this really helped. Fortunately, this time they didn't give me the headphones piping screeching music that was more painful than the MRI sounds. The procedure wasn't great and momentarily I did feel like I was being buried alive. 
The technicians advised me of every different sound, scan movement and length of time I would hear/feel the scanner moving. I was really grateful for this and told them so. It made such a difference to my anxiety levels. Fortunately, it wasn't too noisy and very strangely I started to nod off! I managed 15 minutes in that scanner and owe it to the compassionate technicians. Thank you so much :-)

title: Consultant who tells you as it is..
body:
So my second appointment via Rapid Access service with a Consultant.  Considering my first experience for an ultra sound was horrible I was very apprehensive.  However I met a Consultant who just says it how it is, which can come across rude but I actually felt it was refreshing and increased my trust in him and his capabilities.
I have future appointments at this hospital and I hope the first experience was just a one off.

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

title: Poor Communication
body:
My Dad is in hospital and we are not allowed to visit. Dad is elderly and unable to use his mobile phone.

Which means the only communication we have is via the ward. I rang over 60 times on Sunday and the ward have not answered the phone.  

When you are not allowed to visit these phone calls are extremely important and it is unacceptable that phone calls go unanswered.

title: Terrible needs total overhaul
body: You get told to call the practice at certain times and then when you do they put you on hold for 20-30 odd minute just to say that there are no appointments left I tried 4 different times and eventually had to call the out of hours hub to been seen really bad service seems like there set in the Stone Age still needs totally overhauling new premises and definitely new staff

title: Terrible
body: I'm just annoyed with the quality of this clinic. My wife is in a state of severe depression and cannot get a doctor's appointment! Only by phone! Okay, I registered her for a phone consultation. After 2 days, the doctor or sister called, but my wife, who does not understand English well (especially in her condition), asked for an interpreter. This ended the telephone conversation. No more phone calls ... The person is simply left without help !!! She can't go to a psychiatrist without a referral from a JP doctor. It's just some wildness in one of the richest countries in the world.

title: Nightmare getting appointments for my own needs
body: I used to recommend everybody to switch to doctor Stephenson!! I had very bad mental health In 2016. I was recently diagnosed bipolar & other mental health issues. And I was there every day! I felt like I had nobody and I was scared of what I was going to do and I used to ring every day and they would tell me to come in and they were brilliant with me. Specific doctors were so worried about me that they were ringing up just to check was I ok. They chased things up with the cpn, I used to see a counsellor from mind at the doctors surgery, they made sure I was only given a short perscription so not to have too many tablets at once, always made sure I had a follow up appointment after every paper perscription I was given. They would fit me in when they had no appointments, when my medication wasn’t helping they got me reassessed with pysciatrist for a different treatment plan, Absolutely amazing how serious they took me. And I am forever grateful because I feel like if I hadn’t been taken so serious I’d not be here. But it’s hard for me to speak to someone about what I want to speak about at the moment. Because the e consult on the website isn’t on anymore. So you have to ring at 8am for reception to ring you back, fair enough but it’s personal issues about my mental health that I want to see the doctor about and by the time the reception calls me back I’m at work and it’s not the type of thing I can discuss at work. Even a few times ive spoken with reception and got a same day appointment but it’s by telephone and so I havnt got a specific time and I don’t have anywhere private to take the telephone call. A few times this has happened where I’ve been unable to talk about my problem so I’m suffering, There should be an option online to make discrete appointments for people with mental health problems. Sometimes I’ve rang up at 8am and by time reception calls back they have said they have no same day appointments, no routine and call back Such and such day because that’s when more appointments are released. I hope that my comments will be taken on board and that hopefully something might be able to be put in place for people like me. I havnt got a cpn and the waiting lists are long to get back into mind

title: The worst experience with a hospital ive ever had.
body:
My partner had fallen down the stairs and hurt her tailbone which led to reduced mobility and all round pain while moving.

111 advised she needed an xray at a hospital and sent us here.
We got there and were once again advised that an xray was needed.
Once more she was told you need to wait for an xray by another, different member of staff.

Our initial time to be seen was 40 minutes, not too bad i thought.
After an hour and a half it was a bit long in the tooth but i thought its worth the wait.
After 3 hours we checked with reception who advised us only an hour and a half more.

After SEVEN HOURS OF WAITING on Sunday she finally got in to see a doctor who poked it and said "yes you've damaged your tailbone" and only gave a prescription because it was asked for. Shrugging at any of the questions that were asked of him.

No xray because "theres no point, we can only prescribe pain medication for this"

No prescription painkillers because it was 9.30pm on a Sunday and the pharmacies are closed, nothing.

At any stage we could have been told that the wait time was this long but we were strung along.

At any of the moments throughout this awful, awful day someone could have advised that all can be done is painkillers.

Nobody told her this, they let us both wait for SEVEN HOURS in a chargeable car park for something that could have been resolved at a GP.

Thanks 111 for the great advice
And thanks Rotherham hospital for wasting 7 hours of our lives.

readBy.name: Sarah Champion's Office, MP for Rotherham

title: Didn't get a call back
body: Was meant to have a call back in 20 minutes and I didn't I put the form in twice and nothinv I can't ring myself cause if anxiety and won't go hospital unless it's necessary and still waiting for the call back a day later

title: Impossible to get appointments
body: Despite a multitude of claims below about getting a new phone service they clearly haven’t. They also claim to be first come, first served, this absolutely is not the case, the reality is if you are lucky to get through then you will get served, as there is no queue system on the phone lines it is absolutely not first come, first served. For those of us seeking help with stress related conditions this is a system from a doctors that only ends up making it worse for patients. It’s a disgrace and they are not doing anything to make this better.

author: Agoodcupoftea
title: Recent Admission to Lincoln County Hospital
body:
I was recently admitted to Lincoln county hopsital following a visit to A&E after coughing up blood. I experience frequent chest pain which I'm being investigated for but the concern was the blood.  
Whilst conducting blood tests (BBG) they discovered I had low bi carb and my PH was off meaning I was acidotic. Despite arguing with the ED doctor about being admitted they explained I need to be treated as this was serious and the cause needed to be identified so I agreed. It all went down hill from there.  
I received No communication whatsoever about what was happening with my care once I was admitted. I was only seen by a Dr twice during my 5 day stay and on one of those occasions the Dr was arguing with me about why I was admitted as they had lost my blood results showing the acidiosis and repeatedly told me to calm down and saying I was imagining things, despite the fact I had already received the 12hr iv fluid treatment for the acidiosis. After telling them to send me home then as that was the only reason I was admitted miraculously my results appeared. I didn't even get an apology when they found them.  
I then had to ask to be tested for a kidney infection given I was acidotic and had low bicarb as this shows the issue was with my kidneys. After being told no by the Drs but then speaking to a nurse who agreed I needed to give a sample, it was tested and low and behold I had an infection and was then treated for that.  
Off topic slightly, but on one of the wards I could audibly hear the nurses making fun of me and laughing about a condition I am being investigated for that is in my notes due to their lack of understanding. Making jokes that my conditions acronym stood for psychotic syndrome and that I was a psycho when I hadn't even spoken to these nurses and had been nothing but polite. I think they often forget that even from the nurses station they can be heard.  
One evening I was refused my antibiotic as it was "too late to have it" because the nurse had forgotten to give it to me on time but this was then marked as I had taken it on my chart when I had not. I was then moved wards and the communication got even more dire given I was placed on a surgical ward as a medical patient. This apparently happens frequently and several of the other women in my bay were also medical outliers as they called us. Nurses told me they didn't know what to do with us as they were surgical nurses and a surgical ward and had to "Google" the condition I was being investigated for as they had never heard of it before.  
When asked if we would be seeing a Dr we were told that the medical Drs don't tend to review when we're on surgical wards and this meant noone was able to request to go home when at this point I'd rather have gone home and gotten worse than stay a minute longer. I was told I was waiting for cardiology only to then be told on the Monday that cardiology weren't coming as I was being seen outpatient and my condition is better assessed in that environment, something I had been saying all along.  
I was then exposed to covid-19 which I understand is unavoidable but the person had been on the ward for nearly two days before getting their results. Once they had been moved and the bay put in isolation it felt like a get everyone home and quick activity. Myself and another patient were still on the bay when a team of 4 decided to come in and start stripping the curtains and the ward and then a team of 8 came in and stared the deep clean with intense and strong chemicals that triggered my asthma to the point I was coughing with chest pains requiring my inhaler and another person was vomiting. The people doing the deep clean were from theatres and expressed how sorry they were but that they had been forced to start even though we were still in there, saying there were patients in A&E who were more important, and that we were going home anyways.  
Due to my asthma being triggered an extremely kind nurse got me out of the room and allowed me to wait outside for my paperwork and medication. Three hours prior to this I had been told my paperwork was already completed though only to be told it hadn't been started. Then when I got my discharge paperwork it was not even correct with why I was admitted in the first place, nor that I was acidotic and treated for this, or that I had a kidney infection. It also didn't mention that the consultant had told me I had viral bronchitis.  
I got in the car to go home and sobbed my heart out. There was a ward sister who spent time with me during my stay and explained things to me that is a credit to the hospital and also the nurse that got me out of that room during the covid clean. I would not recommend any of my family or friends attend this hospital and I apologise but I am grateful to be moving home so that I do not have to fear being admitted to LCH again and the emotional upset it caused me, from being made to feel like I'm lying due to Drs losing results, nurses making fun of me and having no communication at all.

author: claymar45
title: Hearing aids.
body: I keep asking for batteries and tubes but I never get tubes. I need new tubes.

author: waterloo
title: Treated as a child at the dialysis unit
body:
I attend the dialysis unit regularly at the Vale of Leven Hospital for treatment.  
Although most of the nursing team are exceptionally nice and go out of their way, I feel insecure when I am dictated to when I am weighed, and if my weight is over 74kg it's not fair that only one nurse has to give me a row. I feel like I am spoken to like a child by this one nurse who is always in what I feel is a bad mood. For the past month I been feeling depressed and really not wanting to go to my dialysis sessions through the week.  
Another matter I would like to address is the abrupt manner of one other staff member whose attitude towards patients is unacceptable and also needs addressing. This should not be happening, as yesterday I left the unit in tears when I got home. I am a grown adult, not a child 😔

readBy.name: Office of Jackie Baillie, MSP for Dumbarton

author: Dementia Carer
title: Leg dressings
body:
My husband, who has dementia, has his dressings changed twice weekly. The surgery is able to do them midweek and it was arranged by Tissue Viability that District nurses would change them at the weekend. I feel that the service provided is very hit and miss with nurses turning up on the correct day sometimes and not others.  
The tissue viability nurse arranged for these visits because he needed the dressings changed more often than once a week and therefore Saturday was arranged to be the day it was to be done. I obviously have to be there and so wait in for the the DN, having got the room ready for his legs to be washed and redressed with the dressings I lay out ready. I usually phone to find out if they are coming, and have had various reasons given for them not coming, including a day change to Sunday without our agreement, not being booked in at all and on a couple of occasions phone calls to say they won't come and asking me to rebook.  
Whilst I realise that this is an overworked service and maybe sometimes urgent cases take precedence, I think that my husband and other people like him should be able to rely on this service as it is necessary for his legs to be dressed and for him to be as comfortable as possible. Another point I would like to make is that it seems that not everyone looks at his notes either on your computer which are the most up to date, or in the folder before doing his legs. Some nurses don't always want to follow the care plan exactly as far as the type and number of dressings they have to apply.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: Rosemary97
title: My stay at lincoln hospital
body:
I was admitted yesterday my gp and they decided I need to stay in I had to wait 3hrs for a bed then a person was placed in the bay and kept us all up - in fact patients were discharging themselves cause they couldn't handle this very rude annoying person. Even nurses told them to stay in their bed, they didn't listen, didn't flush the toilet - there was toilet paper everywhere. if some one buzzed, this person was in everyone's bay to see who it was  
Asking for pain relief after waiting an hour I didn't still get any and then asked again about 30mins later it arrived that's right 1hr30 waiting for pain relief yes they was short staffed maybe more staff would of helped the situation  
Then I had breakfast at 8am was told I was nil by mouth for a ct scan at 4pm I asked for something to eat after the scan they said u can't eat till the scan had been reviewed at 10pm still being starved I was moved to an other ward who confirmed to me I didn't need to be starved at all and at 11pm I actually got some food I was starved for 15hrs for nothing I know I'm fat but come on

author: Wee Lucy
title: My elderly mum's recent admission
body:
My 90 year old mum was admitted by ambulance, to initially ward 16, then on to Ward 20. During her time in hospital she received wonderful care from her doctors and nurses. During her stay they stabilised mum, sorted her meds and she was happily discharged home today to her own home where she lives a very independent life. Whilst this was a very positive experience and we are very grateful for her care I would like to relate some feedback which was not so positive.  
I received a phone call from Ward 20 to say that mum was being discharged and as her bed was needed she had been sent down to the waiting area in Ward 6 and I could go and collect her. When I arrived at the Ward they advised me that whilst mum was indeed in the waiting area she could not go home as her medication had not been dispensed and wouldn't be ready for approximately two hours. The problem with this is that nobody advised me of this when they rang to say mum was discharged. I had left work early to go the hospital to get her and would therefore have to sit with her for two hours, which I am sure under current Covid restrictions is less than ideal, given that hospitals are trying to limit foot fall. I decided to take mum home and arranged for a relative who works in the hospital to collect her medication when it was ready later that afternoon. I feel that the Ward should have given me all the information relating to mum's discharge to avoid me making a journey to collect her when she was not actually ready to leave. I was just fortunate that I had someone to call upon who worked in the hospital who could collect her meds later that afternoon. Another issue that arose when I arrived at Ward 6 to collect mum I was that I was asked to sign a track and trace log, which is fine, however, this log was a sheet of paper sitting openly on a desk at the waiting area. I was astounded to see that I was being asked to provide my name, my address, my date of birth and my telephone number. This seemed to me to be unnecessary information that was being gathered for track and trace purposes. Surely a name and telephone number would have sufficed, what on earth use was my date of birth. What was more problematic was that this log was on full view for anyone to look at and when completing my information I could see everyone else's personal information as would anyone else completing the log. I do not think that personal data should be handled and managed in this way and on full view for others to see. The log should be kept privately and the ward staff should be asking for the information and completing it so as to prevent every Tom, Dick and Harry seeing other people's information. Also I think the amount of data that was being gathered, such as a date of birth and address simply was not required for track and trace. I understand that for staff to gather the data could be problematic in terms of finding the time in their busy days, so perhaps to mitigate the sharing of people's very personal information they could consider limited the information to a name and phone number.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Mpositive
title: Unnecessary overnight stays
body: I have a planned biopsy at the Beatson but I have to go the day before in the early afternoon for a procedure the next day. I tried to arrange that I come on the day as it seems unnecessary and I value my limited time. It seems that if you aren’t in a bed, staff will give it to someone else and I wouldn’t receive my procedure. Isn’t this a waste of resources? As a patient with a life limiting illness, it’s such a waste for me to sit around all day in a bed and probably not sleep much the night before.

author: glyne lock
title: A pain in my ear
body: I have a pain in my ear and was told I have a booking. I have now ask about my booking as I have been in pain for over 4 weeks. I now have been told I have no booking so all what I had been told had been done by was not accurate so now have to start all over again with my own doctor. I have worked all my life and when I need help for the pain I am in all they do is give you pain killers but not check you over as to your problem. I had a hearing test and yes they said to have a hearing aid. yes just a quick fix but not what maybe required to sort the pain and hearing problem. so what do I think of the service at this moment very poor . lets see what they do next

readBy.name: Plymouth University Health and Human Sciences students, 2018

author: cepheussf43
title: They are brilliant
body:
Hello, I get my podiatry done at John Mitchell in Newry. Now, Finton done my feet, he was excellent, an inspiration, he really cares for us. I've had a great experience from all people in John Mitchell, each and every one of them do a great job and have a smile for everyone.  
I was in this Monday past, he done my feet, we had a chat, and as he stood up to give me some privacy, as they all do, I saw the rosary in his tunic. He explained he had gone through a traumatic time, and he wore the rosary through the whole time and he still wears it now, so I can say, Finton, who has gone through so much and come out the other side so lovely, so jolly, so willing to help people: you are brilliant.  
The first person to see me at podiatry was Marla, but I think she has retired now. But each and every person at John Mitchell is amazing, from the receptionist to the people that come round, they are all so welcoming, lovely, lovely people. I couldn't thank them enough, they are so accommodating.  
I took a bit of a toe infection and treated it myself - I'm a diabetic type II, so I'm entitled to get the appointments - but I thought, no, there are other people that need the care and attention more than me - so I cut the sandals off, put the creams on and everything, and it started to heal up nicely - but would you believe it, the infection came back.  
So I rang up last week, explained the situation, and they were instantly understanding and said to come in at a quarter past eleven, told me to phone my doctor as soon as possible to sort out some antibiotics. So I did this and came in on Monday and saw everyone, and everyone has been so great during these difficult times, and even before these times, they are so great, so welcoming, so lovely all the time. We are just so lucky to have them.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: MartyC
title: First Colonoscopy
body:
Went to Forth Valley hospital today for a colonoscopy as a result of small traces of blood found in my biennial bowel cancer test.  
Heard all the usual horror stories about Moviprep and colonoscopy procedures, but the Moviprep is nothing more than a means to flush out the bowel and I could do it again without any concerns.  
The experience and care in the hospital was way beyond my initial expectation (mild fear!) Staff were reassuring, supportive and just outright kind from start to finish. Diane, Emma & Pamela made me feel very relaxed through the colonoscopy. These ladies were simply brilliant and a credit to the NHS. I feel sure that many patients in the Forth Valley hospital receive similar treatment, but today was about me and I was so satisfied, I had to write this review.  
Very well done to all who are connected to this brilliant department

author: Chlst75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: A great place
body: The staff here couldn’t be any nicer and helpful. The doctors however some are nice and some would just stand in the door way and shout over to you in your bed which isn’t really a way of effectively communicating with people. I refused my dinner until I got to speak with a doctor as I was meant to have an examination twice and it was then cancelled on 2 different occasions. Sometimes you have to shout to be listened to. All the nursing staff here are great for answering any questions you have to the best of their abilities. The cleaning is immaculate. When I has suspected c. diff and was put in a side room a member of the domestic team said to me when I had a motion to just buzz them and they would be down immediately to clean which they were. They are incredible. The food is also great too and even better as I’ve been off the cigarettes for 1 week now so getting my taste back gradually which helps too. The staff from the bottom to the top here are all amazing on this ward.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Chlst75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: The nurse was a shining star
body: 4 north is a great ward to be on. In particular there is one nurse called Kathyrn I was actually looking to get a form to fill out great feedback about. I just really wanted to give her a special thanks in particular she really went above and beyond for me and just made be feel great, a true shining star. All the staff are great here as a whole too. One negative to note I have is just about an encounter I had with a staff member serving tea in the evening. I was poured a cup of tea and I politely said no thank you as I don’t drink tea but that they could give it to the lady sitting next to me. They said no and then poured it down the sink. I just thought this was a little unnecessary and they could have simply said okay no problem. I felt there was a bit of a negative attitude. Everything aside from that minor bad experience has been excellent.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Sunflower3
title: Physical activity coaching for cancer patients
body:
I have just completed a 12 week physical activity online course with Joe from Belfast Trust, funded by Friends of the Cancer Centre. My course started back in March 2021. Initially I filled out a questionnaire about my health and completed a 6 minute walking and 30 second sit to stand assessment. Subsequently for 12 weeks I took part in a physical activity session online along with several other cancer patients.  
The exercises were explained and demonstrated by Joe. They were easy to follow . You could complete them at your own pace with encouragement and advice from Joe as you did them.  
I found the sessions very beneficial and enjoyable. I certainly improved as I continued week on week.  
With the COVID situation it is difficult for cancer patients in the middle of treatment to get out and about. I found these online sessions so useful. During times when I was unable to get out much they provided much needed exercise and movement.  
Joe is very approachable and encouraging. The exercises are gentle and manageable. I would certainly encourage anyone considering online exercise to join .  
My 12 weeks finished with a final questionnaire and a walking and sit to stand assessment.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: sjd!
title: Transition support
body:
Adam's House have recently supported the transition to their service of a young man whom was accessing emergency respite, following the breakdown of his placement within the family home. Adams house staff have supported him well, ensuring they took the time to get to know him prior to him moving in, engaging with professionals and his family in order to ensure they could learn as much about him as possible. He has settled in quickly to the placement, loves his new room and is building up positive relationships with his staff and peers.  
it has been great to see how quickly he has settled and I hope he continues to do well.  
A job well done! Thanks to Ady and his team.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: ethoma
title: Wheelchair delivery and adjustment
body: My husband suffered a severe stroke this year, he was discharged from the hospital on the 10th June and the wheelchair he came home from hospital in was unsuitable, which meant he was bedbound as we had a hoist and sling but nowhere to hoist him into. Over two weeks later someone came out to the house to review the wheelchair and another wheelchair was ordered to suit my husband. It was delivered a week later and as my husband was in bed and no one to hoist him into the chair I was given instructions by using an allen key how to adjust the head piece. Later that day when the carers arrived he was hoisted into the chair but nether me nor the carers could adjust this and my husband was in some pain while we tried. For three days now I have tried to reach the OT by phone to no avail, this morning I was contacted by the office and told it would be at least 2 weeks and maybe more before someone could come out to address this problem. I find it hard to believe that there is only one person in the whole company that can do this. Once more after all this time my husband is bedbound, very emotional and fed up and who could blame him for this.

author: avocetwh64
title: Post-stroke assessment and treatment
body:
My husband had a stroke Christmas 2020, at a much younger age than would be expected. Received treatment quickly and treated very well at the stroke unit at Crosshouse Hospital by fantastic and knowledgeable medical and nursing staff.  
Since then, with exception of a very helpful OT he finally saw in June 2021, he has spoken with a stroke nurse twice by telephone - from February 2021, and spoken with his GP two-three times via phone. Both of whom, since he started experiencing significant pain in his foot, which keeps him awake at night on top of existing post-stroke fatigue, have not offered any assessment or advice and have strangely focused instead on denying it is related to his stroke - despite not even seeing him to evaluate. It is like he imagined having a stroke. The GP twice now over the last two-three months when he has finally given in to the pain and called to make an appt to discuss it, has refused to see him and has on both occasions said the pain will either be due to a historical problem with his back, or his mental health and suggested, on both occasions, he use some hypnotherapy CDs. The irony here is that I think it's the lack of someone taking him seriously will begin to affect his mental wellbeing. Talk about diagnostic overshadowing. He is certainly feel hopeless about being taken seriously. And if it is disc related pain it is not clear how hypnotherapy will help assess and treat this either.  
My husband has been trying various exercises and foot supports already via his own investigation. The stroke nurse also via phone - has never seen him face to face or even via the much heralded NHS Near Me, though who did helpfully refer to OT earlier- also decided it will be plantar fasciitis and not related to his stroke. It is like they are all denying he had a stroke- which has been seen on MRI, treated with thrombolysis, and has impacted his health in other ways. And are making various diagnoses over the phone.  
The OT - who has no problem visiting patients face to face at home or elsewhere -consulted a physio colleague who thought it would be most likely post-stroke pain, given the specific nature of his symptoms but advised the waiting list for physio is 8 months, and much longer for neuro physio assessment- so he saw a physio. They examined my husband and said it was likely post stroke pain due to no inflammation of the plantar area in his foot and his symptoms. Still the GP, by phone (again) says refuses this diagnosis and says it will not be due to his stroke and offers a phone (yet again) consult this time with the surgery physio, whom we have never been told was available at the surgery, or assessment offered - who today 'assessed' him via phone, and yet again, said it may just be a co-incidence the pain followed his stroke and it would be unlikely to be caused by the stroke. They have however offered him a face to face appt in a week. It feels like banging your head on a brick wall, no one is listening. No tips, even for exercise or stretching etc have ever been offered, for whatever the pain may be. Instead, they are more interested in bending over backwards to prove my husband does not have pain in his foot, and if he does, to say it isn't caused by his stroke, than actually offering to see him for a quick appt face to face and and helping him. It's not a big ask. Having a stroke and living with the aftermath is hard enough.  
My husband continues to work well in his career, albeit at slightly reduced pace, and is keen to keep working. He is trying to stay positive. He has never had a mental health problem, though was naturally in a bit of a shock in the immediate weeks after his stroke. To be faced with denial from his GP practice and stroke professional who won't even see him face to face and being told his foot pain and altered sensation is a historical back problem or a mental health problem (without even investigating these if this were so!) and repeatedly pushed to accept hypnotherapy CDs is downheartening, bizarre and extremely frustrating, and at worst I feel it is prolonging any damage done by his stroke. Why they cannot just agree he has had a stroke and offer assessment and then physio or nerve medication at very low dose to alleviate his pain as appropriate in relation to whatever is causing his pain is odd. To blame it on his mental health is extraordinary - and I say this as an experienced mental health professional. And to do all this via telephone over a period of months risks something being missed, and again further prolonging any damage done by the stroke.  
In my opinion, none of this demonstrates good quality care or best practice in terms of even the basics of person-centred care or post-stroke assessment or treatment. And I also thought we were beyond those days of blaming physical health issues on mental health.

author: Kim4
title: Colonoscopy
body: I had a colonoscopy at forth valley and feel like I received such amazing care from the team.

author: Madz0912!
title: So thankful
body: Daughter had a problem with eyes, doctors weren’t keen to intervene and signposted us to opticians, an appointment with in half an hour and a hospital appointment within the hour, ointments prescribed and a follow up appointment within the week! So thankful for our NHS!

author: Kitiara
title: PTSD and a health anxiety
body:
I had intrusive and vivid memories about my husband when he was ill with cancer 7 years ago. He died at age 43 and it was traumatic. This also triggered a health anxiety and I was constantly panicking about every ache and pain, thinking it was cancer. I also had job related anxiety due to working on child protection teams and this was affecting how I viewed the world and I was paranoid about the safety of my children.  
My counsellor was knowledgeable, friendly, supportive and professional. I felt able to talk openly and the work she did with me has changed how I feel and given me more understanding and coping mechanisms.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: Acarer56
title: All staff were so pleasant
body: Was a bit anxious but all staff were so pleasant and explained everything well. It was so nice to chat to the lovely nurses & endoscopist after being in lockdown for so long. They made me feel very comfortable and we have a bit of banter and laughter. Although the actual procedure was not very pleasant the staff couldn't have been nicer. They are doing a wonderful job after such a bad couple of years.

author: Shezbot3000
title: Breastfeeding Support
body: With essential support from birth, NHS Lanarkshire Infant Feeding Team were prompt in ensuring I had the correct position and attachment from the word go including home visits and video calls. At 6 weeks despite our feeding journey going smoothly my baby boy began to get frustrated, lose weight and hurt me in the process. The Infant Feeding Team gave up their time days on end to support us at our lowest and aren’t willing to give up until they find an answer. I’ve never once felt rushed, pressured or judged and I honestly don’t know what we would do without them.

title: COPD
body: I had a booked appointment with the COPD Specialist Nurse who failed to turn up.  I was very disappointed because I had not had my condition checked for at least 3 years.  I have not received any apology.  A very kind nurse at the surgery noticed I had been waiting for a long time so arranged for me to be seen.  I am grateful to her.

title: improving quality of service
body: visited practice after a long time nice to see improvements in quality of care had to speak to their manager regarding some concerns about my dad's medication and long waiting ques on phone she explained current situation very briefly and politely and promised to make things more better she is very  professional and approachable .

title: Gynaecology Cobridge good visit
body:
Very convenient practice to visit, easy to park etc
Quiet 
Consultant very informative, pragmatic, reassuring.
Next/follow up appointment will take place a lot sooner than waiting for the main hospital.

author: Tealeaf32
title: Maxiofacial
body: I developed a lump near and under my right eye November 2019 and seen my GP January 2020. They advised if it got any bigger to get back in touch. It did indeed get bigger so back to GP in October ( via telephone and sending in pictures due to COVID) who referred me to maxiofacial at Crosshouse hospital. I hear nothing at all from them and eventually called in March 2021 and told there is a significant waiting list but to go back to GP if my vision is affected. This lump has grown huge and my vision is affected now so back to GP again (via phone call/pictures ) in early July who then made an urgent referral. More than a month on and still no contact. Called them to be told there is an 80 week waiting list. I am so disappointed and upset not to mention worried this lump is possibly cancerous. I feel let down by this department!

author: Donut74
title: Took the time to explain everything
body: I went to Ultrasound department 1st then straight up to the clinic. From the minute I walked in the door I felt at ease, lovely nurses and nurse practitioner, took time to explain everything what was going on, in detail, and how they was going to deal with my problem. A credit to the hospital.

title: Unsafe service
body:
I have been trying to book an appointment for three days, after first trying and being told that appointments can no longer be booked in advance and will not be for the foreseeable future. 

Since then I have waited hours to be spoken to, before being told that no appointments are available. I have spoken to both livi and pushdoctor, who have advised that I need to be seen at a face-to-face appointment. Today I finally got through and was given a phone appointment in the afternoon, where a doctor would decide if I could be seen face-to-face. This, despite the fact that a doctor via the recommended pushdoctor service has already decided that I need to be seen face-to-face.

I do not want to take up space in A&E, but it seems impossible to be treated at this gp practice. It is essentially out of service as it is almost entirely unavailable. This is not a safe situation for all those registered here.

title: It could be great
body:
When you get through a GP here they can be amazing. The problem is their management.

I called today and the reception asked what it's about,I told her it was related to my HIV which is late stage and life threatening and she asked if it could wait until next week.

Extremely disappointed,I understand that every GP and medical institution is under so much pressure but you shouldn't have to declare to a receptionist what you're calling about, then for them to decide if it's worth their time today or not.

I hope they manage the practice better in the future,I won't be a patient there much longer.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

title: Lovely nurse
body: I had a smear test with a lovely nurse who put me at ease, talked me through it and was so kind. I've had no other experience with the practice but my appointment was really great. Thank you.

title: Great
body: It has always been a pleasure with doctors and nurses as per visit/telephone appointments, particularly within the last 2 years consultations. The last 2 GP doctors I have consulted were  very supportive and has excellent advise. Just (15/08/21,Sunday) yesterday my GP called me to reveal the check blood test done last week due to some abnormality on previous blood test done. This particular GP has a good heart and I appreciated her call even it was a Sunday. My thoughts was, she called me so not to be worried about the previous blood test abnormal findings. It has relieved my stressful time thinking about my health. It was indeed a 5* rating. Thank you!

title: Great staff
body: I was advised by my GP to attend Ward 23 AMU on Friday evening with suspected DVT and possible TIA. Yes the waiting times are long and it is difficult to sit for such a long time. I was treated very professionally and the staff were cheerful in what I would describe as difficult circumstances. Staff that I observed were pleasant and courteous to patients who were waiting. I would hope that once the covid situation eases both staff and patients have an easier time. Even though the department was very busy drinks were offered twice whilst I was there.  My phone was out of charge and a member of staff kindly acquired the correct charger so that I could contact my husband.

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

title: Really good experience
body: From entering the building where the volunteer was really kind, welcoming, and helpful through to the reception staff the process of getting seen was quick, smooth, and the waiting area was vey calming. The medical staff were all great in particular the medic and the nurse I saw me had a great 'bedside manner' and, insofar as having seven staples in your head can be, made the whole experience almost enjoyable. Very impressed, again, with the service from Southmead hospital.

title: Terrible service
body: Phoned at 9.00am to make an appointment and was told I would receive a call back from the doctor that day. At 18.20pm I rang again to be told I had not been placed on the call back list (don't understand why) but would be called the next day. Having now twice submitted photos requested for the doctor to look at (both texts were acknowledged) I rang the next day for the  third time - and was asked to re-submit photos again and was told no photos were received nor was I on the list for a call back, but that this would be remedied and I would be called. Not sure whether the technology of saving files is fully understood by staff, as in all cases the photos were acknowledged as received but not saved to my file. Needless to say I am still waiting and in the meantime had to make other arrangements to resolve a medical issue which could have been serious. No wonder people go to A&E. Just dreadful.

author: Ani7
title: Ableism at UCLH
body:
I am a wheelchair user. I can not physically put pressure on my legs as this causes excruciating pain in my pelvic. I was admitted to UCLH because I was in a lot of pain that day for a separate emergency.  
I stayed overnight whilst waiting for a bed to be available in a ward. They did not let me take my wheelchair as I came with the ambulance and my mother who is my full time carer was not allowed to come with me to help me. The problem that I had was that every time I needed to use the toilet I had to ask the nurses for a wheelchair. In the first instance after being admitted to the emergency department, I asked for a wheelchair to allow me to use the toilet. The staff told me they didn’t have any wheelchairs available and left.  
I then asked for a commode and they told me they did not have one at that moment. I asked if they could give me anything to hold onto and again they said no. I was so desperate that I had to get up and hold the walls and anything around me whilst crying out in pain just to use the toilet. I thought I was going to collapse. That was the most painful thing I have ever had to do.  
I was then moved to a different part of the hospital for checks. I thought maybe things would be better from there. I was very wrong. Whilst in desperate need for the toilet I waited around 10-15 minutes each time for a nurse to get back to me. If I was able to walk I could easily walk to the toilet myself when I needed too. As a wheelchair user I needed someone to push me and take me to the toilet and help me. I can not count the amount of times I had to ‘hold it in’ and bare the excruciating pain which is associated with my condition.  
When they did finally find a wheelchair for me after waiting another 30 minutes the nurse took me to the toilet and when I was finished and waited for them to push me back to my bed I had to sit in the wheelchair in the toilet for another 10 minutes calling out to someone for help.  
Throughout this whole experience the only relief that I had was when they allowed my mum to visit me after begging the nurses and she brought my wheelchair and assisted me as she usually does. I also used a commode twice which was fine until I couldn’t properly clean myself without help. I tried not to drink anything as I knew that I would need the toilet and would have to wait a long time for a nurse to push me.  
I have never in my life been more disappointed and disgusted with the health care system. I feel embarrassed and ashamed as a disabled person. My basic human needs were not met and I can not imagine how many more people have and will experience the same thing. It is very clear that being disabled or less abled is a burden that could not be catered to on this occasion in an NHS hospital.

readBy.name: Plymouth University, BSc (Hons) Urgent and Emergency Care 2022

author: Min78
title: Worry and anxiety
body:
I contacted the service after a lot of different life factors started to become too overwhelming and was causing me immense amounts of worry and anxiety whereby I was not sleeping well or wanting to do anything.  
From the initial phone call to the sessions, every person I spoke to was caring, kind and empathetic and genuinely wanted to help me. My sessions ended up being with a Trainee Psychologist Wellbeing Practitioner named Natasha. She was very kind, listened intently and gave very helpful advice and ways in which I could manage my worries. She helped me a lot and was very easy to talk to, I found myself using her ideas and implementing them which helped to turn around all of my anxiety and worry. It was ok to worry and be anxious but it didn’t have to over rule my life. I’m in a much better mindset now and I hope that it continues.

author: Apr25
title: The care that I received was excellent
body: A big thank you to everyone at the Endoscopy Unit at Lincoln County Hospital. The care that I received was excellent. The process was quick and efficient and what to expect during my procedure was explained perfectly which gave me reassurance. The kindness and good humour of the team who performed my procedure helped me immensely. The environment is also lovely and clean.

author: LaurenG21
title: Very caring staff
body: The staff Miss Harper; Jackie and Olivia made me feel at ease as soon as I walked in the room and throughout the LLETZ procedure. Very caring staff. Thank you for making this procedure as easy and less stressful as possible.

author: Nicole30
title: Covid 19 vaccination
body: Brilliant staff, 10/10. The woman who gave me the vaccine was great at calming me as I am terrified of needles. Great asset to our healthcare service.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Polite, Attentive and Helpful.
body:
From the moment I spoke to the receptionist I felt at ease, she was very helpful. The consultation with the doctor wasn’t rushed, he reviewed my test results, listened to my thoughts, and made recommendations that suited my needs.
During these troublesome times I have found Phoenix Family Care staff, receptionists, doctors, practice nurses to be very mindful of their responsibilities to their patients. Thank you all.

title: Blood Tests
body: I wasted two hours of my working day having to go to Bedford for a blood test, the whole process of which took less than one minute.  Why - when Houghton Close has a Phlebotomy unit??  I don't drive and taking a bus there and back when I'm supposed to be working is infuriating.  I don't suppose I'll get a reply ...

author: Ricochet_95
title: My experience with ADHD services
body:
In 2018, I made a gp appointment to be assessed for ADHD after thinking I may have it for a while. I decided to do this as I was at university and having a diagnosis could give me extra support at uni. I had my first appointment at the start of 2019 and was told then that I most likely do have ADHD and someone would be in touch to make a second appointment with my mum.  
2 years later, in February 2021 after calling multiple times to ask when my appointment would be, I was told I was lost in the system. They apologised and set up an appointment with the covering psychiatrist for 2 weeks later. When I had this appointment I was told that they couldn't do anything as they had none of my original notes and I would have to wait for the person who had seen me previously to be available. I then put a complaint in as I felt I was not getting the care I deserved.  
On the back of this, I was given another appointment with the covering psychiatrist where I was given the diagnosis then had a follow up to start meds. The person I originally saw was coming back a week later so was told that my follow up from starting the meds would happen with them.  
We are now 20 weeks down the line and still have not had a phonecall or appointment to even ask how I am getting on with these controlled meds. I have called no less than 5 times within this time. The first few times, (about 5/6 weeks after starting meds) I was told there was a lot to catch up on, and that I'd get an appointment in due course. I called again last week and was told that a staff member is leaving and they have no replacement yet so cannot make me an appointment or tell me when I will get one.  
I feel this is totally unacceptable. Especially since I started a controlled drug with no support or follow up in the slightest and no one seems to be able to help me.

title: Poor accessibility
body: The telephone line is permanently busy. The automated answering system recommends using the website to book appointments. The website proudly announces that the booking system has been suspended as has several other services. So you phone again, and after going through the automatic system you are told that you are 12th in a que. …………….I have got a better chance of winning the Derby on a 3 legged racehorse than getting through. So I give up trying, not withstanding my enquiry is in response to a request from the surgery to contact them.

title: Wonderful Care in Endoscopic Unit
body: Spent a day in this unit being cared for by brilliant staff who kept me totally informed throughout and looked after me in a most caring and professional way… The kindness shown to me made what could have been a dreaded experience into ‘nothing to worry about we are going to look after you’ THANK YOU ALL

readBy.name: Wirral University Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Rude and unhelpful reception staff
body: I have called the surgery for an appointment this morning at 8.02am for me and my daughter. I was told no one appointment per person . I asked for a prebookable appointment for my daughter and was simply told ‘No’. She told me there was only one appointment left today . I do not believe this after being open for 2minutes. Then I was asked why I wanted the appointment , I gave my explanation and was told she needed more detail as it was triage and if there was somebody more poorly I wouldn’t be given the appointment . Surely, I do not need to discuss my personal and private health concerns with the reception staff. If I wasn’t concerned I wouldn’t be calling the doctor . I asked for the manger and was told she didn’t work today. I was phoning the GP as I am in extreme pain and worried about my health, the attitude of the person taking the call was a disgrace.

title: Excellent
body:
I was referred by my GP to Peterborough Hospital to see the consultant regarding a hernia earlier this year, I had the operation on Friday 13th August & the whole procedure from start to finish  has been   stress free.
All appointments have run like clock work, & the day of the operation was exactly the same, I cannot speak highly enough of the care that I received from all the staff.
This is the third operation I have had at Peterborough Hospital ( knees last time) & my experience was excellent then.
My thanks to all the staff

title: No very plasent
body:
Been on the phone for ages and I was on 18th position and when it was my number message came up saying we helping other customers please call again 
So annoying 
Please sort out your phoning system or hire more people.

title: Friendly helpful practice
body: It is such a lovely practice friendly and helpful , every doctor and nurse I have seen have been really nice , especially the nurses who I have to visit regularly

title: No appointments!
body:
Monday 16th August 2021
I have just been in a queue for an appointment for half an hour only to be told there are no appointments available - this is at 9am. I was contacted at the weekend to make a telephone appointment because of results of blood tests I had on Friday 13th August.  I was then offered an out of hours appointment in a week. This is really not acceptable. So I am going to try to get an appointment tomorrow. Let’s see if I am able to receive medical attention

title: Absolutely awful practice
body: This doctors surgery is the most awful practice myself or any of my family have ever experienced. For over a month I have been ill and been in contact with the doctors, which is hard enough to get through as the phone lines for making appointments have the smallest open windows. I have been messed around, and told to call a different number/day/time/place, on every single phone call, and offered no help at all. I was even sent to a hospital out of my way to  get all the way there and be sent away with them saying they don’t even provide the service I was sent there for! I have been waiting over a week for a call back from my GP and it is just not good enough at all. People are ill and need to be cared for which they are not getting from this surgery, it needs to be sorted out.

title: Impossible to get seen face to face
body: I have been at Pulteney Practice for about two years and have now left due to finding it impossible to get seen face to face. I had to pay for private therapy for my mental health after a doctor told me ‘what do you want to do about it now, we’ve exhausted all options’. The final straw is the fact I have had recurrent uti and kidney infections over the last two years. I have already had 4 this year and have not been seen face to face once despite begging for someone to see me and for someone to investigate. The surgery have even lost my samples for testing! I left the surgery this morning and joined another who had a doctor call me within 15 minutes; I already have a face to face appointment at a surgery on the same day I joined. I am hugely disappointed by the service at Pulteney, I understand times are hard at the moment but patients MUST be seen face to face.

title: Great Services
body: I was here due to an OD, the staff were brilliant with me and was always making sure I was okay. Highly recommend.
